awd_titl_txt: Non-Commutative Spaces, Their Symmetries, and Geometric Quantum Group Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The project fits within the scope of the branch of mathematics known as noncommutative geometry, originating primarily in the discovery early in the 20th century that the then-newly-discovered phenomena of quantum mechanics require a novel mathematical formalism. The main point of departure from classical (or non-quantum) mathematics is the fact that by the very small-scale nature of our ambient world, certain pairs of measurable physical quantities cannot be measured simultaneously (with the momentum and position of a particle serving as the preeminent example). Mathematically, this manifests as the non-commutativity of a pair of transformations on a physical system, justifying the name "noncommutative" for the relevant field of study. The formal objects that model the symmetries (that is, structure-preserving transformations) of a physical system modeled according to this paradigm are known as a "quantum groups", and they are the central theme of the present research proposal. The training of graduate students is an important part of this project.

A number of broader themes inform the problems under consideration. As one example, discrete quantum groups, like their classical counterparts, fall into a constellation of taxonomic classes based on the approximation properties enjoyed by their group algebras. The quantum versions of the classical results are typically more technically demanding, only partially settled, and good test beds for the strengths of the geometric-group-theoretic and operator-algebraic techniques that jointly make classical discrete groups such rich geometric and analytical objects. In another direction, much light can be shed on the structure and above-mentioned approximation properties of quantum groups (discrete or more generally, locally compact) by category and representation-theoretic means. For that reason, results to the effect that group-theoretic data (e.g. the center of a locally compact quantum group) can be reconstructed from categories of unitary representations with their underlying structure are of some interest in the field and the project. As a third example, randomness features heavily in the study of groups and other discrete objects (probabilistic methods are very important in graph theory, for instance); the general phenomenon whereby a "generic" object, constructed randomly (with the technical meaning of that phrase depending on the specifics of the problem) tends to be highly asymmetric appears to replicate in the quantum setting, with "most" finite graphs, finite metric spaces, etc. admitting no quantum symmetries. Such generic rigidity results always recover their classical counterparts (given that quantum symmetries always encompass ordinary ones), but usually require more involved and often more enlightening proof techniques. It is hoped the requisite eclectic mix of approaches to the problems (combinatorial, representation-theoretic, probabilistic, operator-algebraic, etc.) will offer insight not only into the nature of the quantum-mathematical objects ostensibly being studied, but also into the classical versions thereof.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project funded by award DMS-2001128 revolved around problems in non-commutative geometry, a branch of mathematics ultimately rooted in mathematical physics. The structures and concepts involved have been gaining currency and ascendancy with the advent of quantum mechanics at the beginning of the twentieth century, and are frequently inspired and motivated by developments in that field and adjoining ones. In a necessarily inadequately brief summary, the driving paradigm is that of recasting geometric structures and objects algebraically and employing the relevant algebraic or analytic tools in their study. The geometric structures in question include, for instance, the space-times mathematical physicists use to model the universe, or phase spaces aggregating the possible states of a mechanical system (a rigid object in motion, a collection of moving particles, etc.). 

The results stemming from the work carried out under the project's umbrella have been and are being disseminated in a number of ways: publications in peer-reviewed technical journals (mostly mathematics, some mathematical-physics-oriented) and conferences, workshops and seminars where the PI has presented said work. The funding has contributed to forging and strengthening collaboration among researchers based at numerous institutions around the world: Belgium, Canada, the Czech Republic, Germany, India, Israel, Poland, Romania, the United Kingdom and so forth. Projects acknowledging the award involve, in total, somewhere in the neighborhood of 40 coauthors.

The relatively broad appeal of the problems forming the object of the award has helped lay the groundwork for future collaboration: many of the projects carried out jointly with the above-mentioned coauthors are longer-term propositions, ongoing at the time of this writing. Award DMS-2001128 has thus arguably served successfully as a scaffold for future work, providing a rough directional backbone grounding subsequent developments and novel, emerging problems. 

Some of the technical journals where part of the work resulting from the project has appeared in print include: Algebras and Representation Theory, Applied Categorical Structures, Archivum Mathematicum, Bulletin of the London Mathematical Society, Communications in Algebra, Discrete Applied Mathematics, Documenta Mathematica, Forum of Mathematics Sigma, International Journal of Mathematics, Israel Journal of Mathematics, Journal of Algebra, Journal of Combinatorial Optimization, Journal of Functional Analysis, Journal of Lie Theory, Journal of Mathematical Analysis and Applications, Journal of Noncommutative Geometry, Journal of Operator Theory, Journal of Pure and Applied Algebra, Journal of the Korean Mathematical Society, Kyoto Journal of Mathematics, Michigan Mathematical Journal, M{\"u}nster Journal of Mathematics, Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society, Representation Theory, SIGMA, Selecta Mathematica, Theory and Applications of Categories, Topology Proceedings, Transactions of the American Mathematical Society. 

In addition to funding the PI's research directly, DMS-2001128 also budgeted for graduate-student support, in the form of tuition and salary for periods of focused research. Over the course of the project the PI has supervised three doctoral dissertations at the University at Buffalo, all having produced work adjacent to the problems germane to the award; some of that work has been published jointly in the Journal of Pure and Applied Algebra and SIGMA (peer-reviewed mathematics journals). One other PhD student is also currently working under the PI's guidance, on problems having to do with enriched categories and fibrations thereof.

Technical aspects of thesis-oriented research aside, the funding has also contributed to the doctoral students' professional development at a crucial early stage in their careers: there are logistical aspects of academic research work that require practice and training to master, such as making effective use of bibliographic resources, recording partial progress efficiently, assembling a presentation or paper and disseminating research outcomes through publication. All of these activities, naturally, take place more intensely during periods of increased attention devoted to research such as those afforded by the award. 

The funding provided by the award has also facilitated other work involving early-career mathematicians. The PI's coauthors on one research project initiated and completed under the scope of the award, for instance, since published in the Journal of Algebra, were at the time a doctoral student (advised by one of the PI's colleagues) and a postdoctoral associate respectively, both affiliated with the University at Buffalo. The above remarks on the benefits of mentoring for graduate students also apply, to an extent, to colleagues in postdoctoral positions: engaging in the mechanics of collaboration can only have a salutary effect on those colleagues' professional development during their early careers. 

As to work dissemination (beyond publication proper), the award has contributed to conference travel as a matter of course. Recent examples include, for instance, sectional meetings held by the American Mathematical Society in Cincinnati, OH (Apr 15-16 2023), Fresno, CA (May 06-07 2023) and Savannah, GA (Oct 05-06 2024), an address at the Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (May 15-19 2023), and the University of Waterloo Analysis Seminar (May 09 2024). The PI has had the opportunity to report, there, on results stemming from several projects funded in part by award DMS-2001128.
